description: The Apple Certified Technical Coordinator certification is designed for anyone responsible for managing Apple computers and devices in a business environment. The exam is made up of content from the Support Essentials ACSP course, as well as content from the Server Essentials course which is covered in this show. Technologies covered include topics like network deployment, policy management, troubleshooting and using Open Directory for centralized user management.
name: Certified Technical Coordinator 10.10
subtitle: OS X Server Essentials 10.10

episodes.description: In this episode Don walks us through the Apple Certified Technical Coordinator certification. He takes a look at the topics covered, as well as basic information on how to take the exam.
episodes.title: Apple ACTC Overview
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:07,144
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07,144 --> 00:00:08,040
In this segment,

3
00:00:08,040 --> 00:00:11,569
we're gonna take a look at
the Apple Certified Technical Coordinator

4
00:00:11,569 --> 00:00:13,060
certification.

5
00:00:13,060 --> 00:00:16,820
The ACTC is the highest level
certification from Apple for

6
00:00:16,820 --> 00:00:17,820
IT professionals.

7
00:00:17,820 --> 00:00:19,220
Now, who is an IT professional?

8
00:00:19,220 --> 00:00:22,980
Well, these are people that work in
businesses, enterprises, government

9
00:00:22,980 --> 00:00:27,670
organizations schools that are responsible
for supporting Apple computers.

10
00:00:27,670 --> 00:00:31,920
Right.
And this spans from MacBooks to Mac Pros

11
00:00:31,920 --> 00:00:36,040
to iPads to iPhones, all the various
Apple devices that are out there.

12
00:00:36,040 --> 00:00:38,650
Most of them are designed for
consumer level use.

13
00:00:38,650 --> 00:00:40,240
Right.
Just regular home users that have

14
00:00:40,240 --> 00:00:41,480
a single device.

15
00:00:41,480 --> 00:00:44,380
But when we deploy them in a corporate
world or an educational world,

16
00:00:44,380 --> 00:00:47,980
where you might have hundreds,
thousands, tens of thousands at Mac.

17
00:00:47,980 --> 00:00:51,210
There's actually some really cool
administrative software available

18
00:00:51,210 --> 00:00:55,330
to help do that, to help provide a unified
environment even though we have a large

19
00:00:55,330 --> 00:00:59,680
quantity of these devices, and
that's what the ACTC is all about.

20
00:00:59,680 --> 00:01:04,500
Now, if you've landed here,
you've probably already taken the ACSP,

21
00:01:04,500 --> 00:01:07,250
the Apple Certified Support Professional.

22
00:01:07,250 --> 00:01:12,540
If you haven't, the ACSP is the first
step along the way of getting your ACTC,

23
00:01:12,540 --> 00:01:14,696
the Apple Certified Technical Coordinator.

24
00:01:14,696 --> 00:01:16,850
If you're gonna be working
as a help desk technician,

25
00:01:16,850 --> 00:01:20,030
if you're gonna be helping
people work with their Macs,

26
00:01:20,030 --> 00:01:24,840
that's what the ACSP is designed for,
the Apple Certified Support Professional.

27
00:01:24,840 --> 00:01:27,360
But if you're gonna be running
a larger organization,

28
00:01:27,360 --> 00:01:30,840
if you're gonna be the big picture person,
the person that says.

29
00:01:30,840 --> 00:01:33,280
I've got hundreds of thousands of Macs.

30
00:01:33,280 --> 00:01:35,040
How do I get them all talking together?

31
00:01:35,040 --> 00:01:38,750
How do I get them able to locate
each other across multiple networks?

32
00:01:38,750 --> 00:01:40,820
How do we provide that infrastructure?

33
00:01:40,820 --> 00:01:41,800
That's what the ACTC is for.

34
00:01:41,800 --> 00:01:42,300
All right.

35
00:01:43,370 --> 00:01:47,870
Now where it gets confusing,
is kind of how the exams are structured.

36
00:01:47,870 --> 00:01:51,800
If you want to get the Apple Certified
Technical Coordinator certification,

37
00:01:51,800 --> 00:01:54,080
there's actually two exams
that you have to take.

38
00:01:54,080 --> 00:01:58,790
There's the exam for the ACSP, for the
Apple Certified Sport Professional, and

39
00:01:58,790 --> 00:02:02,120
there's a separate one that's designed for
server.

40
00:02:02,120 --> 00:02:03,950
Let me show you on Apple's website, so

41
00:02:03,950 --> 00:02:06,650
we can kind of make this
as clear as possible.

42
00:02:06,650 --> 00:02:09,160
Apple's website is
training.apple.com/certification,

43
00:02:09,160 --> 00:02:13,090
and that's where they have all
their certifications laid out.

44
00:02:13,090 --> 00:02:14,140
They've got certifications for

45
00:02:14,140 --> 00:02:17,110
IT professionals,
as well as creative professionals right.

46
00:02:17,110 --> 00:02:18,860
The design and graphics people.

47
00:02:18,860 --> 00:02:21,710
For us, we're dealing with
the IT professionals side.

48
00:02:21,710 --> 00:02:23,660
And if you take a look,
they've got certifications for

49
00:02:23,660 --> 00:02:26,470
the different versions of
Mac OS that have come out.

50
00:02:26,470 --> 00:02:32,430
So we see 10.9 Mavericks and
10.10 Yosemite, we're doing 10.10.

51
00:02:32,430 --> 00:02:35,050
And if you jump in there,
they lay out the certifications.

52
00:02:35,050 --> 00:02:38,100
Now there's the entry level
Apple Certified Associate, or

53
00:02:38,100 --> 00:02:39,740
ACA certifications.

54
00:02:39,740 --> 00:02:41,920
That's for people just getting started.

55
00:02:41,920 --> 00:02:43,850
And they're really good certifications.

56
00:02:43,850 --> 00:02:45,640
The courses are fairly short.

57
00:02:45,640 --> 00:02:47,350
The exam fee is really low.

58
00:02:47,350 --> 00:02:49,690
You can take it right from
the comfort of your own home.

59
00:02:49,690 --> 00:02:52,160
Really straightforward
certification to get.

60
00:02:52,160 --> 00:02:56,120
If you don't have any Apple certifications
at all, that's really the place to start.

61
00:02:56,120 --> 00:02:57,560
But, it's not required.

62
00:02:57,560 --> 00:03:02,190
If you've been working with Macs for
years, you can skip right past the ACA and

63
00:03:02,190 --> 00:03:05,700
jump right up to the ACTC if you want,
right.

64
00:03:05,700 --> 00:03:10,300
Now, most people start with the ACSP,
the Apple Certified Support Professional.

65
00:03:10,300 --> 00:03:15,988
There's one exam that goes along with it,
and that exam is called the OS 10 or OS X.

66
00:03:15,988 --> 00:03:18,040
Support Essentials 10.10 exam.

67
00:03:18,040 --> 00:03:21,110
All right, so
that's the first exam that we take.

68
00:03:22,120 --> 00:03:26,130
If you want your ACTC,
you need to take a second exam.

69
00:03:26,130 --> 00:03:28,750
You've got the Support Essentials exam and

70
00:03:28,750 --> 00:03:32,600
then you've also go
the OS X Server Essentials exam.

71
00:03:33,800 --> 00:03:37,290
Support Essentials,
that focuses on workstations,

72
00:03:37,290 --> 00:03:40,610
desktops, laptops how we keep them up and
running and healthy.

73
00:03:40,610 --> 00:03:45,050
But the server essentials that
dives into the server app and

74
00:03:45,050 --> 00:03:49,010
a lot of the extra infrastructure that
a regular end user is never gonna see or

75
00:03:49,010 --> 00:03:51,350
know about but
they're gonna use it all the time.

76
00:03:51,350 --> 00:03:54,980
They don't just realize it,
it's all transparent in the background.

77
00:03:54,980 --> 00:03:59,030
So that's the server essentials one,
now you can take these out of order,

78
00:03:59,030 --> 00:04:00,200
if you want.

79
00:04:00,200 --> 00:04:04,350
If you do the server essentials first,
you actually do get awarded the ACSP.

80
00:04:04,350 --> 00:04:06,820
They don't show that on the site,
but you do.

81
00:04:06,820 --> 00:04:10,640
If you take just the server essentials,
you will take the ACSP, but

82
00:04:10,640 --> 00:04:15,250
you still don't get the ACTC
until you pass both of them.

83
00:04:15,250 --> 00:04:17,440
Right, now if you're just getting started,

84
00:04:17,440 --> 00:04:19,580
you should definitely
check out our ACSP show.

85
00:04:19,580 --> 00:04:22,860
We've already filmed all the material for
that 10.10 Yosemite.

86
00:04:22,860 --> 00:04:25,280
You can jump in there, watch it,
get that certification.

87
00:04:25,280 --> 00:04:25,892
That's where you start.

88
00:04:25,892 --> 00:04:27,200
All right.

89
00:04:27,200 --> 00:04:31,330
But if you just wanna learn about
server or if you've already pass ACSP,

90
00:04:31,330 --> 00:04:36,670
then it's time to move into this one
into the OS 10 server essentials course.

91
00:04:36,670 --> 00:04:39,580
And here's where we start to
learn the advance infrastructure.

92
00:04:39,580 --> 00:04:41,320
When you've passed that exam,

93
00:04:41,320 --> 00:04:45,720
you're now awarded the Apple Certified
Technical Coordinator certification.

94
00:04:46,800 --> 00:04:48,940
There is an upgrade path,
that's what they're showing here,

95
00:04:48,940 --> 00:04:50,500
the re-certification exam.

96
00:04:50,500 --> 00:04:53,412
If you were certified under
10.9 Mavericks, or 10.8, or

97
00:04:53,412 --> 00:04:56,920
anything earlier, you can just
take the re-certification exam.

98
00:04:56,920 --> 00:05:01,660
It covers material from both of the other
exams, though, so it's the same content.

99
00:05:01,660 --> 00:05:03,960
You still have to know
the same information, but

100
00:05:03,960 --> 00:05:05,660
it's just all grouped
together right there.

101
00:05:07,040 --> 00:05:09,950
All right, now,
let's talk a little bit about the exam.

102
00:05:09,950 --> 00:05:12,980
On Apple's website they had these
exam preparation guides and

103
00:05:12,980 --> 00:05:15,850
they are great to use to
structure your studying.

104
00:05:15,850 --> 00:05:18,200
They're a great way to know
what to expect on the exam.

105
00:05:18,200 --> 00:05:21,405
And to make sure that you've learned all
the material that you need to learn,

106
00:05:21,405 --> 00:05:22,190
right.

107
00:05:22,190 --> 00:05:23,580
Use it as a checklist.

108
00:05:23,580 --> 00:05:25,340
I'm gonna pull up the one for
Server Essentials here.

109
00:05:25,340 --> 00:05:28,026
I'll just go that exam
preparation guide and

110
00:05:28,026 --> 00:05:31,072
we'll pull that one up We
will go in English today.

111
00:05:32,733 --> 00:05:33,453
Here we go.

112
00:05:33,453 --> 00:05:34,869
And in this document,

113
00:05:34,869 --> 00:05:38,760
it will have everything you
need to know about the exam.

114
00:05:38,760 --> 00:05:41,235
And they lay it out in a pretty
straightforward process.

115
00:05:41,235 --> 00:05:42,760
Right.
They explain the certifications,

116
00:05:42,760 --> 00:05:46,210
what I was just talking about a moment
ago, but here's the really cool part.

117
00:05:46,210 --> 00:05:49,000
Here's where they tell you
about the exam itself.

118
00:05:49,000 --> 00:05:49,550
All right.

119
00:05:49,550 --> 00:05:50,800
So what do we need to know?

120
00:05:50,800 --> 00:05:53,907
Well, the exam number is 9L0-525.

121
00:05:53,907 --> 00:05:56,140
We need to know that for
when we schedule the exam.

122
00:05:56,140 --> 00:05:59,290
When you're ready to sign up for
it, you go to Apple's web site and

123
00:05:59,290 --> 00:06:00,710
you sign up to take that exam.

124
00:06:00,710 --> 00:06:06,690
Now, the exam is proctored through
Apple Authorized Training Centers, AATCs.

125
00:06:06,690 --> 00:06:08,550
And you can go to Apple's website and
do a search.

126
00:06:08,550 --> 00:06:10,670
I'll put a link in the notes for this.

127
00:06:10,670 --> 00:06:14,400
That you can click on to go and
find the nearest testing center to you.

128
00:06:14,400 --> 00:06:16,120
Sometimes they're right in
the same city as you, and

129
00:06:16,120 --> 00:06:17,630
that works out really convenient.

130
00:06:17,630 --> 00:06:18,400
Sometimes you're like me.

131
00:06:18,400 --> 00:06:22,510
I have to drive two hours away to get
to the nearest AATC to take exams or

132
00:06:22,510 --> 00:06:23,990
to take official courses.

133
00:06:23,990 --> 00:06:25,420
So you can jump over and do that.

134
00:06:25,420 --> 00:06:28,080
But you can find those
listed right on the website.

135
00:06:28,080 --> 00:06:30,430
The exam is a computer based exam.

136
00:06:30,430 --> 00:06:32,060
It's 80 questions long.

137
00:06:32,060 --> 00:06:33,740
And you get two hours, all right.

138
00:06:33,740 --> 00:06:36,170
So two hours for
eighty questions really not that bad.

139
00:06:36,170 --> 00:06:38,840
You get about a minute and
a half per questions.

140
00:06:38,840 --> 00:06:39,720
A little bit more.

141
00:06:39,720 --> 00:06:41,990
And you jump through and
you take care of it.

142
00:06:41,990 --> 00:06:44,520
Most of the questions are multiple choice.

143
00:06:44,520 --> 00:06:47,980
But there are some drag and
drop and visual elements as well,

144
00:06:47,980 --> 00:06:51,640
where they'll show you a screen
capture of the server app, and

145
00:06:51,640 --> 00:06:54,970
they'll say, where would you go in
this to perform a certain action?

146
00:06:54,970 --> 00:06:55,740
And so you've gotta click.

147
00:06:55,740 --> 00:06:57,540
They have hotspots on the image.

148
00:06:57,540 --> 00:06:59,050
So, you get different
questions of that nature.

149
00:06:59,050 --> 00:07:01,370
But, most of them
are just multiple choice.

150
00:07:02,730 --> 00:07:07,630
Be aware that on Apple exams,
you do get partial credit for questions.

151
00:07:07,630 --> 00:07:09,700
So, if you get a question
that says something like

152
00:07:10,890 --> 00:07:14,140
choose three of the following that
provides such and such feature,

153
00:07:14,140 --> 00:07:16,450
and they give you a list of 10 items.

154
00:07:16,450 --> 00:07:20,260
Well, if you get two of the three right,
you actually do get partial credit.

155
00:07:20,260 --> 00:07:22,230
Some of the other exam vendors
out there like Microsoft,

156
00:07:22,230 --> 00:07:24,180
they don't do partial credit,
but Apple does.

157
00:07:24,180 --> 00:07:27,100
So make sure even if
you're not positive of

158
00:07:27,100 --> 00:07:29,410
the answer that you at least go ahead and
fill it in.

159
00:07:29,410 --> 00:07:31,499
Because the parts that you do get right,
you will get credit on.

160
00:07:32,880 --> 00:07:35,820
There's a couple of other things,
there is a little confusion.

161
00:07:35,820 --> 00:07:36,840
Let's see, did they say it here?

162
00:07:36,840 --> 00:07:38,240
Yeah.
There's a little confusion on this

163
00:07:38,240 --> 00:07:42,382
line right here, that the exam includes
five unscored demographic questions.

164
00:07:42,382 --> 00:07:43,750
All right.

165
00:07:43,750 --> 00:07:46,330
There's some people out there that say,
well what that means is you actually get

166
00:07:46,330 --> 00:07:48,790
80 questions and
five of them are unscored.

167
00:07:48,790 --> 00:07:51,050
But what really is is
there's 85 questions.

168
00:07:51,050 --> 00:07:54,190
There's a little five question survey
at the very beginning that asks some

169
00:07:54,190 --> 00:07:55,180
demographics.

170
00:07:55,180 --> 00:07:58,480
Basically how much experience you have.

171
00:07:58,480 --> 00:07:59,640
Have you worked with Apple products?

172
00:07:59,640 --> 00:08:00,820
How did you study?

173
00:08:00,820 --> 00:08:01,320
Things like that.

174
00:08:01,320 --> 00:08:02,600
And those are unscored.

175
00:08:02,600 --> 00:08:06,400
But you will have 80 actual
scored questions on the exam

176
00:08:06,400 --> 00:08:07,490
spread across two hours.

177
00:08:08,650 --> 00:08:14,080
Now the exam covers a wide range of
topics and [LAUGH] they lay it out

178
00:08:14,080 --> 00:08:19,670
in just like painful detail right here
across 30 pages or something like that.

179
00:08:19,670 --> 00:08:22,290
But I'm gonna go up to the table of
contents, it's a little bit easier to take

180
00:08:22,290 --> 00:08:26,570
in the exam content's divided
up into seven areas alright.

181
00:08:26,570 --> 00:08:30,840
It starts out with configuring and
monitoring OS X server, right.

182
00:08:30,840 --> 00:08:34,730
We need the server app to
turn our Mac into a server.

183
00:08:34,730 --> 00:08:38,640
And it adds a lot of functionality
that technically was there already but

184
00:08:38,640 --> 00:08:42,620
now becomes visible on the graphical user
interface It's all hidden by default.

185
00:08:42,620 --> 00:08:44,660
So we can bring that out
with a server app, but

186
00:08:44,660 --> 00:08:47,760
we need to understand, how do we install
it, how do we get it configured,

187
00:08:47,760 --> 00:08:50,390
how do we get it running, and
how do we keep it running.

188
00:08:50,390 --> 00:08:52,130
And that's what that first section covers.

189
00:08:52,130 --> 00:08:54,120
This is the biggest section
of the entire exam.

190
00:08:54,120 --> 00:08:57,050
A lot of the exam content comes from
right out of this very first part.

191
00:08:58,290 --> 00:09:02,620
Then it divides the rest of the content
into more specific areas, right.

192
00:09:02,620 --> 00:09:04,450
Part two is configuring accounts.

193
00:09:04,450 --> 00:09:06,090
These are local user accounts for

194
00:09:06,090 --> 00:09:10,280
a Mac as well as centralized user
accounts in an open directory.

195
00:09:10,280 --> 00:09:13,659
If you've never worked with open
directory, it's really cool software,

196
00:09:13,659 --> 00:09:14,715
it's very powerful and

197
00:09:14,715 --> 00:09:18,063
definitely something you'll want if
you have more than a handful of Macs.

198
00:09:19,435 --> 00:09:23,580
Then we do managing devices
with configuration profiles.

199
00:09:23,580 --> 00:09:26,810
If you just have one Mac, you set
things up right there on the Mac and

200
00:09:26,810 --> 00:09:28,120
you just do it by hand.

201
00:09:28,120 --> 00:09:30,640
But if you have 1000 Macs,
you dont want to have to go and

202
00:09:30,640 --> 00:09:33,750
configure every single one of
them it would take forever.

203
00:09:33,750 --> 00:09:38,720
So with configuration profiles we can
create a standard configuration for

204
00:09:38,720 --> 00:09:42,450
our Macs, and we can roll that out, either
roll it out after the Macs are already out

205
00:09:42,450 --> 00:09:45,070
there or
we can build it into our deployment image.

206
00:09:45,070 --> 00:09:47,801
So that when we first install
Mac OS on the system it's already

207
00:09:47,801 --> 00:09:51,055
configured the way that we want it,
it already has the software we need and

208
00:09:51,055 --> 00:09:52,803
it's ready to run right out of the box.

209
00:09:54,219 --> 00:09:55,311
Part four is sharing files.

210
00:09:55,311 --> 00:09:57,425
Right.
How do we exchange information between our

211
00:09:57,425 --> 00:09:59,547
systems and
that one's pretty straight forward,

212
00:09:59,547 --> 00:10:00,990
not a whole ton to deal with there.

213
00:10:01,990 --> 00:10:03,990
Part five is deployment solutions.

214
00:10:03,990 --> 00:10:07,810
I mentioned just a minute ago that we
could make images that already have Mac OS

215
00:10:07,810 --> 00:10:11,160
set up the way we want it and roll it out
onto the network, well how do you do that?

216
00:10:11,160 --> 00:10:13,260
That's what we'll cover
in deployment solutions.

217
00:10:13,260 --> 00:10:17,500
We'll get a chance to see how
to do scheduled network repairs,

218
00:10:17,500 --> 00:10:19,980
how to build an image and
deploy it over the network and

219
00:10:19,980 --> 00:10:22,830
do a lot of this stuff without
even having a USB key or

220
00:10:22,830 --> 00:10:25,820
bootable media you can do it right from
the network, really cool stuff there.

221
00:10:27,120 --> 00:10:29,690
Part six is providing network services.

222
00:10:29,690 --> 00:10:32,500
And this one's actually a collection
of different technologies.

223
00:10:32,500 --> 00:10:36,230
In the server app,
there's a lot of functionality in there.

224
00:10:36,230 --> 00:10:40,120
Things like automatic updates and
cashing services, DNS.

225
00:10:40,120 --> 00:10:43,120
All of these various network services that

226
00:10:43,120 --> 00:10:46,230
taken individually aren't all that
powerful but put together as a whole,

227
00:10:46,230 --> 00:10:48,870
really creates an amazing
network infrastructure.

228
00:10:48,870 --> 00:10:50,140
And we'll take a look at that in part six.

229
00:10:51,400 --> 00:10:54,360
And then the very end, part seven,
is collaborative services.

We're gonna take a look at email and
chat, FaceTime.

231
00:10:58,030 --> 00:11:01,180
Some of the different ways that we
communicate between our users and

232

how we deploy that in
a server environment.

233
00:11:03,750 --> 00:11:07,220
How we can keep a lot of that local
instead of relying on internet services.

234
00:11:07,220 --> 00:11:09,770
So if we're trying to maintain privacy and
security.

235
00:11:09,770 --> 00:11:11,270
We don't wanna use an internet service for

236
00:11:11,270 --> 00:11:14,350
that we'll get a chance to
see how to use the server.

237
00:11:14,350 --> 00:11:16,520
So really powerful stuff.

00:11:16,520 --> 00:11:19,860
If you attended the ACSP training if you

never launched that server app at a single

time, and
the reason is we do it right here.

All this is based on the server
app inside of Mac OS, and

242
00:11:30,470 --> 00:11:33,670
a little bit of Remote Desktop, we'll see
how Remote Desktop goes in there too.

243
00:11:33,670 --> 00:11:35,290
But most of it's done with the server app,

244
00:11:35,290 --> 00:11:38,920
we'll get a chance to see all
the stuff that it can do, really cool.

245
00:11:38,920 --> 00:11:41,820
Your regular end user doesn't
need this information.

246
00:11:41,820 --> 00:11:45,320
Your help desk professional typically
doesn't need this information, but

247
00:11:45,320 --> 00:11:49,870
if you're one of the system engineers or
even an information system manager or

248
00:11:49,870 --> 00:11:51,000
somebody like that.

249
00:11:51,000 --> 00:11:53,930
You're the big picture guy, you're trying
to think of the infrastructure that's

250
00:11:53,930 --> 00:11:56,652
needed to support your Macs,
this is what you want to know.

251
00:11:56,652 --> 00:11:58,000
All right.

252
00:11:58,000 --> 00:12:01,540
So it is an advanced topic for
prerequisites,

253
00:12:01,540 --> 00:12:03,720
Apple doesn't really have
any prerequisites for this.

254
00:12:03,720 --> 00:12:06,465
Anybody can walk right in off of
the street and take this exam.

255
00:12:06,465 --> 00:12:09,690
Right.
They'll probably fail, but they can do it.

256
00:12:09,690 --> 00:12:15,630
What Apple recommends is that at a minimum
you do the ACSP for desktop support first.

257
00:12:15,630 --> 00:12:17,500
The Apple Certified Support Professional.

258
00:12:17,500 --> 00:12:22,430
You go ahead and take that Support Basics
exam and get that under your belt.

259
00:12:22,430 --> 00:12:25,710
Because you don't wanna be trying
to fix a server problem and

260
00:12:25,710 --> 00:12:28,120

261
00:12:28,120 --> 00:12:31,210
And it could have been something

262

00:12:34,150 --> 00:12:34,980

268
00:12:48,250 --> 00:12:49,380

269
00:12:49,380 --> 00:12:53,010
But there is a seven-day cool
down period in between attempts.

270
00:12:53,010 --> 00:12:54,030
So if you take the exam and

271
00:12:54,030 --> 00:12:57,980
don't pass, you'll have to wait at least
a week before you can take the exam again.

272
00:12:57,980 --> 00:12:59,390
So just be aware of that.

273
00:12:59,390 --> 00:13:02,900
The exam is not the most
challenging in the world, but

274
00:13:02,900 --> 00:13:05,832
it's covering a lot of topics that

275
00:13:05,832 --> 00:13:07,870
All right.

Also remember that this is not

episodes.description: In this episode, Don walks us through how to install the Mac OS X Server App and provides a quick introduction to the various features inside the app. He also discusses the pre-requisites for installing as well as concerns when upgrading to a new version.
episodes.title: Installing OS X Server

episodes.description: In this episode Don walks us through the various name-lookup configurations for Mac OS X Server. He shows how to set the hostname for your server, how to create DNS zones and host records, and demonstrates setting up redundant DNS servers.
episodes.title: DNS

episodes.description: In this episode Don demonstrates the various ways that you can remotely manage a machine running the OS X Server App. He demonstrates SSH, screen sharing and remotely executing the Server App itself.
episodes.title: Remote Management

episodes.description: In this episode Don explains the various uses for certificates in Mac OS X Server. He demonstrates the self-signed certificates created by the Server App, as well as the process for securing publicly trusted certificates for use in Server App services
episodes.title: Certificates

episodes.description: In this episode, Don describes the three primary methods for monitoring an OS X Server to ensure it is online and healthy. He covers logging for past monitoring, statistics for real-time monitoring, and alerts for future monitoring.
episodes.title: Monitoring OS X Server

topics.title: Configuring and Monitoring OS X Server

episodes.description: In this episode Don demonstrates how to configure the Profile Manager to deploy configuration profiles to end user machines. He also shows some of the settings that can be configured.
episodes.title: Configuration Profiles

episodes.description: In this episode, Don demonstrates using the Server App to create share points inside of MacOS. He discusses the various file sharing protocols, and examines the various permissions provided by POSIX and ACL based permission schemes.
episodes.title: Sharing Files
